headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2013. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the conference over to your host, Mr. Bob
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2013. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the conference over to your host, Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As I begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response your questions concerning growth in the storage industry, our position in the industry, our investment in capital allocation p
componenttext:
Thank you. As I begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements in our comments and in response your questions concerning growth in the storage industry, our position in the industry, our investment in capital allocation plans, HDD demand for December quarter and fiscal 2013 in our financial results expectations for the September quarter and fiscal 2013. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our 10-K filed with the SEC on August 20, 2012. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events. 
In addition, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures that we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the investor information summary posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. 
The forward-looking guidance we provide during this call excludes certain items such as amortization of intangibles and the dilutive impact of sales of drives to Toshiba in connection with our divestiture transaction. Because the amount of these items is not fully known to us at this time, we are unable to provide guidance for or our reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. The impact of these excluded items may cause the estimated non-GAAP financial measures to differ materially from the comparable GAAP financial measures. [Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investor section of Western Digital's website immediately following the conclusion of this call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chief Executive Officer, John Coyne.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. I have with me our President, Steve Milligan; and our Chief Financial Officer, Wolfgang Nickl. In this, my last earnings call, I'm happy to report another quarter of strong financial perf
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. I have with me our President, Steve Milligan; and our Chief Financial Officer, Wolfgang Nickl. In this, my last earnings call, I'm happy to report another quarter of strong financial performance continuing our track record of consistent execution. During my 6-year tenure as CEO, we have experienced and successfully addressed many different challenges and opportunities. Throughout, we have continued to hone our time-tested and flexible business model delivering outstanding returns and value under varying scenarios. The results include a doubling of market share, a tripling of revenue and a fivefold increase in profits. 
I'm proud of this sustained performance by the team and I'm confident, as I pass the leadership of the company to Steve, ably supported by Tim Laden, Mike Cordano and Wolfgang, that they will continue to build on that momentum. 
While the macroeconomic environment is dampening near-term demand, we remain confident in the continued long-term growth in the creation, storage and management of digital content. This is being seen in every aspect of our lives and monetizing it provides a compelling long-term opportunity for the company. 
We have built strong relationships with customers in all of our markets by consistently delighting them with high quality, reliable products based on superior technology and delivered through the industry's most efficient supply chain. We have developed a tremendously broad product portfolio, great depth and breath in our people and technology resources and a powerful platform. Western Digital has never been better positioned to succeed as it continues to thrive on change and deliver great value to all its constituents. 
I want to take this opportunity to thank our customers, our supply partners and our investors for their support and I especially want to thank our employees around the world who have consistently delivered such outstanding performance. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. We are very pleased to report strong financial results for our September quarter, demonstrating our continued ability to deliver value under varying market conditions. There are several dynamics currently limiting market demand: First, globa
componenttext:
Thanks, John. We are very pleased to report strong financial results for our September quarter, demonstrating our continued ability to deliver value under varying market conditions. There are several dynamics currently limiting market demand: First, global macroeconomic weakness, which is impacting overall IT spending; second, product transitions in the PC industry; and third, the continued adoption of tablets and smartphones which is meeting PC sales growth. 
These headwinds notwithstanding, the Western Digital team remains focused on creating outstanding economic value, building on our strong multiyear track record. There is a tremendous opportunity as we innovate and enable customers to store, manage and connect the massive and growing amounts of digital data in their personal and professional lives. This opportunity extends well into the future. 
Looking across our markets, the needs of customers are becoming more diverse, resulting in greater market segmentation. Computing is no longer a general purpose opposition and that evolution plays to the strengths of Western Digital with our technology breadth, people and product portfolio. 
Currently, we are focused on 3 key initiatives to broaden our portfolio to meet the evolving needs of our customers, enabling continued value creation. First, the delivery of innovative and cost-effective storage products, including hybrid drives, present and light mobile devices. Second, a portfolio enterprise products that fit the varying needs of the public and private cloud environments, including high-performance, SSD systems and high-performance and large capacity hard drives with the lowest total cost of ownership. Third, providing easy-to-use integrated solutions for the personal cloud environment and our connected lives. 
We have received very positive customer feedback on our latest differentiated solutions to address these trends. All major PC OEMs have shown strong interest in our 5-millimeter and 7-millimeter hybrid designs as an alternative to solid-state and dual drive configurations. 
In the cloud environment, our new 7-disc high-capacity CO drive announcement has been extremely well received, confirming the need to seek better total cost of ownership solutions for this growing market. For the Connected Life, we introduced today the My Passport Enterprise, one of the industry's first portable hard drives designed specifically for use with Microsoft's Windows To Go, enabling corporate customers to provision a fully featured Windows 8 workspace on a USB drive. 
For fiscal 2013, we remain focused on realizing the $10 EPS target established in July of this year, despite a significant change in underlying industry growth assumptions. We will continue to manage closely those aspects of our business that we control namely, delighting our customers, executing to our product roadmap, remaining diligent with regards to managing costs and expenses and strategically allocating our capital. 
Looking forward, I am very excited about the future of Western Digital. We have the people, platform, technology and financial resources to continue to invest in growth opportunities while, at the same time, returning approximately 50% of our free cash flow to shareholders. 
Wolfgang will now provide a report on our Q1 performance and our Q2 outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. I will first summarize our consolidated financial performance for last quarter and then provide a range of expected financial results for the December quarter. Revenue for the September quarter was $4 billion. Excluding shipment to Toshi
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. I will first summarize our consolidated financial performance for last quarter and then provide a range of expected financial results for the December quarter. Revenue for the September quarter was $4 billion. Excluding shipment to Toshiba under our divestiture agreement, we shifted total of 62.5 million hard drives into the market at an average selling price of $62. 
OEM sales represented 63% of revenue; distribution channel sales, 24%; and retail sales, 13%. Our gross margin for the quarter was 29.6%. Excluding $38 million of amortization expense related to acquired HGST intangible assets, non-GAAP gross margin was 30.5%. Our SG&A spending totaled to $575 million for the September quarter. SG&A included $11 million of amortization expense related to acquired HGST intangible assets. 
In order to align our production with anticipated market demand, we incurred charges of $26 million in the September quarter. Net interest and other nonoperating expense was $14 million. Tax expense for the September quarter was $59 million or 10.2% of pretax income. Our net income for the September quarter totaled $519 million or $2.06 per share. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $594 million or $2.36 per share. 
Turning to the balance sheet. We generated $936 million in cash from operations during the September quarter and our free cash flow totaled $554 million. We used $218 million to repurchase 5.2 million shares. As of the end of September, an authorization of $2.6 billion remains available for future repurchases. 
We declared the first dividend in company history in the amount of $0.25 per share for a total of $61 million, which we paid on October 15 to shareholders of record as of September 28. 
We exited fiscal Q1 with total cash and cash equivalent of $3.5 billion of which $826 million was in the U.S. Subtracting our total debt of $2.1 billion, our net cash balance was $1.4 billion.
I will now provide our guidance for the December quarter. We expect a total available market of approximately 140 million units; revenue in the range of $3.55 billion to $3.7 billion, reflecting the muted demand environment, a seasonal reduction in our gaming business and a planned reduction of our 3.5-inch contract manufacturing for Toshiba; gross margin of approximately 28%, excluding the amortization of HGST intangibles, which is within our new business model despite continued cost challenges stemming from the floods in Thailand last year; we expect R&D SG&A spending to be approximately $525 million, excluding the amortization of HGST intangibles; a tax rate of approximately 8.5%; and the share count of approximately 248 million. Accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share of between $1.65 and $1.85 for the December quarter. 
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert Baird.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, wanted to ask Steve about macro, cyclical and secular. I know it's tough to divide that up, Steve. But if you could talk about how much of this is secular versus cyclical assuming the macro comes back and gets better next year, to some more color t
componenttext: First, wanted to ask Steve about macro, cyclical and secular. I know it's tough to divide that up, Steve. But if you could talk about how much of this is secular versus cyclical assuming the macro comes back and gets better next year, to some more color there.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason. You kind of hit the nail in the head. I think that it is -- it's a difficult question to answer. We've got -- as we indicated on our prepared remarks, there's a lot of different factors at play. Clearly, the global macroeconomic environment --
componenttext: Yes, Jason. You kind of hit the nail in the head. I think that it is -- it's a difficult question to answer. We've got -- as we indicated on our prepared remarks, there's a lot of different factors at play. Clearly, the global macroeconomic environment -- I mean and it's not just the IT industry but there's a lot of headwinds in terms of what's happening on a global basis. Additionally, the IT segment is not immune to that, so we've seen other announcements come out that have talked about weakness in terms of overall IT spending. And then clearly, the PC industry is weak, all right. And some of that is due to product transitions with Windows 8. But undoubtedly, there is an impact, as we're seeing, if you want to call it cannibalization, in terms of tablets and smartphones or other kind of connected devices. And I think the important thing for to really refer to is when we had our Investor Day, we talked about a longer-term growth rate in the HDD industry of 3%. When we put that together, we attempted as best as possible to estimate the impact of all these different factors. And right now, we don't see a reason to alter that 3% longer-term growth rate in terms of a number of hard drives sold.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, Wolfgang, you maintained $10 for the full year, you must be assuming gross margins come off of that 28% level in the second half of the year, fiscal year?
componenttext: Okay. And, Wolfgang, you maintained $10 for the full year, you must be assuming gross margins come off of that 28% level in the second half of the year, fiscal year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason. I mean $10 is the target and remains the target. Our company focus is on the items that we control or at least the influence -- we're focusing heavily on task, we're focusing on OpEx in spending. We somewhat impact the share count as well and
componenttext: Yes, Jason. I mean $10 is the target and remains the target. Our company focus is on the items that we control or at least the influence -- we're focusing heavily on task, we're focusing on OpEx in spending. We somewhat impact the share count as well and obviously try to optimize volume price mix decision. So the focusing on what we control or influence. We have made an assumption when we originally stated the $10 target in July, I believe, yes, in July that we assumed the TAM to increase by 5%. And if you do the math, that would be a TAM of 630 million units. And with the first 2 quarter that 139 and 140, respectively, we need a bit of an uptick in the second half of the fiscal year to continue to be able to do the target. I believe that we'll get in the 600 range, it's very doable. And like we said, we focus on the levels that we control and that remains a target. And that's what we're shooting for.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Rob Cihra from Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Next question comes from Rob Cihra from Evercore Partners.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Wondering within the product mix in the quarter, if you could give us any more color both within PC but even more, so I guess on enterprise. How much of that decline in the quarter that you're expecting again? Do you think is inventory drawdown versus act
componenttext: Wondering within the product mix in the quarter, if you could give us any more color both within PC but even more, so I guess on enterprise. How much of that decline in the quarter that you're expecting again? Do you think is inventory drawdown versus actual slowdown in demand? And maybe again perhaps more so on enterprise that given the fact that we kind of already know PCs have been weak, but any view you have with enterprise demand, what it's looking like?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rob. In the enterprise faces a couple of different dynamics going on. First thing is if you go back to the floods, really a couple different things there. First off, the enterprise segment was the one segment that was least impacted from a drive out
componenttext: Sure, Rob. In the enterprise faces a couple of different dynamics going on. First thing is if you go back to the floods, really a couple different things there. First off, the enterprise segment was the one segment that was least impacted from a drive output perspective as it relates to the floods. We all, the various different companies, independently did as much as we could protect the supply in that critical part of the market. Nevertheless, our customers, because of concerns about shortages, I would say bought ahead from a demand perspective in order to protect themselves in that segment. Additionally, if you look at some of the impact of the LTA contracts that were out there, that also resulted in customers purchasing ahead from a supply perspective ahead of the demand. And then, sure, we have seen some slowdown in terms of end-user demand, if you want to refer at with that way. But fundamentally, the overall dynamics in the enterprise space remain positive as we're saying substantial data growth and build out of infrastructures from that perspective. However, in terms of the units that we ship as an industry and we ship as a company, we are seeing the impact of that inventory correction roll through the latest quarter. And hopefully, we'll be able to work through it as we finish out the year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Steve Fox with Cross Research.
componenttext: Next question comes from Steve Fox with Cross Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of clarifications. Just under $10 target just to return there for a second. If you're talking about potentially doing 600 million units in sort of the bogey, what would be the levers that you think you can most control putting aside capital
componenttext: Just a couple of clarifications. Just under $10 target just to return there for a second. If you're talking about potentially doing 600 million units in sort of the bogey, what would be the levers that you think you can most control putting aside capital allocation? Would it be more on the expense side or would it be shipping new products sooner than maybe advertised, et cetera? And then secondly, is there any other mix issues that we should think of maybe over the next couple of quarters within the segments in terms of average capacity, within notebooks versus hard -- versus desktops et cetera as we model out?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, the biggest lever is clearly cost and we're assuming a standard mix between the segments in all 4 accounts.
componenttext: Yes, the biggest lever is clearly cost and we're assuming a standard mix between the segments in all 4 accounts.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add to that, I mean, certainly what we can do on the cost and expense side is always important to manage that in a diligent fashion. But our #1 priority is to continue to take care of our customers. Because if we can earn their trust and
componenttext: Yes. I would just add to that, I mean, certainly what we can do on the cost and expense side is always important to manage that in a diligent fashion. But our #1 priority is to continue to take care of our customers. Because if we can earn their trust and continue to earn their business, that helps provide the runway for a stronger financial results for us.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify, in terms of any kind of excess inventories there is no emphasis on one type of capacity versus another? You're saying it's pretty broad-based?
componenttext: And just to clarify, in terms of any kind of excess inventories there is no emphasis on one type of capacity versus another? You're saying it's pretty broad-based?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that's a good assumption.
componenttext: I think that's a good assumption.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Aaron Rakers from Stifle, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Next question comes from Aaron Rakers from Stifle, Nicolaus.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: First question is sticking to the topic of the inventory, when I look at your finished goods inventory build, standing at 508 million, how do we think about that in the context of gross margin? How does that build flow through the gross margin and how sho
componenttext: First question is sticking to the topic of the inventory, when I look at your finished goods inventory build, standing at 508 million, how do we think about that in the context of gross margin? How does that build flow through the gross margin and how should we think about that line item in reflection of the 28% gross margin going forward? Have you -- I guess another way of putting it, have you aggressively pulled back on your production to see that finished goods inventory come down here going forward?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I mean, first of all, the numbers is up a little bit and that has to do with ocean shipment and also has to do that we were very, very focused on not over shipping to the market at the end of the quarter. In terms of its impact on the 28%, it has an impac
componenttext: I mean, first of all, the numbers is up a little bit and that has to do with ocean shipment and also has to do that we were very, very focused on not over shipping to the market at the end of the quarter. In terms of its impact on the 28%, it has an impact in a sense that if you want inventory down a little bit, you build less drives in the December quarter. And one of the impacts is absorption. To fewer the drive you build and we mentioned the demon to start and we mentioned that Toshiba fact and the fewer in a quarter, the more challenging it is to get your cost objective. So from that perspective, coming in was a little bit of a higher inventory certainly makes it more difficult to get to the gross margin and had a bit of contribution to the quarter-over-quarter decline.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe a follow up, somewhat tied to that but more importantly go looking for it. As I think about the levers in your model and we think about it from a, let's say, COGS per unit basis, you're still running about $45 COGS per unit. I know pr
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe a follow up, somewhat tied to that but more importantly go looking for it. As I think about the levers in your model and we think about it from a, let's say, COGS per unit basis, you're still running about $45 COGS per unit. I know prior to Hitachi are running closer to the mid-30, high-30 range. How do we think about that in the context of getting back to normalized internal versus external heads and where do we stand on the aerial density transition?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm going to give a general comment to that. I think one of the things and I certainly don't mince it'd offensive way but one of the real optimistic parts of our numbers, we put a range out there of 27 to 32 in terms of gross margins. First thing is that
componenttext: I'm going to give a general comment to that. I think one of the things and I certainly don't mince it'd offensive way but one of the real optimistic parts of our numbers, we put a range out there of 27 to 32 in terms of gross margins. First thing is that you would expect that the low end of that margin model would have a higher likelihood of hitting when you're in adverse market conditions, right? So we're at 28%. And the other thing is that if you look at some of the issues that we're facing from a cost perspective and you get out the absorption issues. And not only that, we're still working to get back into a pre-flood cost level. Frankly, at some level at those subs. And then you also look at the dislocation in terms of absorption of kind of a sub-point that as we transitioned out of this Toshiba contract manufacturer situation, we've got to rebalance our factories on the HGST side to do that in a more cost-effective way. You start thinking about that in the context of that 28%. It actually makes that number look a lot more -- look a lot better than what the headline might allude to.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the aerial density transition, we won't provide any particular numbers on that but I can tell you, they were on the very early stages. And as we cut over into the new aerial density, that certainly helps us achieve our target cost as well.
componenttext: And in terms of the aerial density transition, we won't provide any particular numbers on that but I can tell you, they were on the very early stages. And as we cut over into the new aerial density, that certainly helps us achieve our target cost as well.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Bill Shope with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question comes from Bill Shope with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us a little more color on the competitive landscape within the enterprise side of the business. Where the market share's sort of settled out this quarter and how you're thinking about that in your forecast for the Decembe
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us a little more color on the competitive landscape within the enterprise side of the business. Where the market share's sort of settled out this quarter and how you're thinking about that in your forecast for the December quarter and for the full fiscal year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Bill, I'll take that. This is Steve. I think that we have done and this is really on both sides but certainly particularly on the HGST side, we have worked very hard over frankly several quarters to one, fill out our product portfolio, and not only that p
componenttext: Bill, I'll take that. This is Steve. I think that we have done and this is really on both sides but certainly particularly on the HGST side, we have worked very hard over frankly several quarters to one, fill out our product portfolio, and not only that provide a more compelling value equation for our customers. Certainly, in terms of the way that our products function, quality levels, et cetera, et cetera. And as a result of that, we've been fortunate enough to gain a meaningful amount of market share. And we continue to expect to maintain that level. In the past quarter, there were some puts and takes in terms of the different elements of that. We may be a slight bit of share in certain segments but we continue to get -- to not only maintain our momentum but hopefully, if we can continue to do our job, increase our momentum in that space.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the Nehal Chukchi with Technology Insights Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the Nehal Chukchi with Technology Insights Research.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: For the newer line segment, can you first give us what the units were for that? And then secondly, can you try to help us separate out how the enterprise portion of the near line demand trended clearly, that was not very positive and how the cloud portion
componenttext: For the newer line segment, can you first give us what the units were for that? And then secondly, can you try to help us separate out how the enterprise portion of the near line demand trended clearly, that was not very positive and how the cloud portion of newer line trended? And then I have a follow-up segment as well.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll give you the numbers. The TAM was just shy of 7 million units, which was down quarter-over-quarter. And we're not breaking out our specific details between performance and capacity enterprise shipments.
componenttext: I'll give you the numbers. The TAM was just shy of 7 million units, which was down quarter-over-quarter. And we're not breaking out our specific details between performance and capacity enterprise shipments.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at it from a demand perspective, both their traditional performance segment and the capacity enterprise segment were affected by the inventory overhang that we spoke of -- that I spoke of earlier. I would say, and this is our view, tha
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at it from a demand perspective, both their traditional performance segment and the capacity enterprise segment were affected by the inventory overhang that we spoke of -- that I spoke of earlier. I would say, and this is our view, that the inventory adjustment and the capacity enterprise space is behind us. We expect some modest growth in that segment here in calendar Q4. Now just to remind everybody, the demand in that segment, and this is maybe becoming a little bit less so than the past, but it tends to be a little bit more project-based, so it can be a little bit lumpy. But we are anticipating some modest growth here in the final quarter of the calendar year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then could you just discuss the drivers of expected sequential decline in gross margin? Is that purely mix? Or is that -- has something to do with the higher cost component here?
componenttext: Okay. And then could you just discuss the drivers of expected sequential decline in gross margin? Is that purely mix? Or is that -- has something to do with the higher cost component here?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll take a crack at that, Nehal. First of all, I think Steve mentioned earlier, we have a range of -- in our gross margin model, 27% to 32% that provides that -- at certain times, we have different utilizations. Our different with product transition
componenttext: Yes. I'll take a crack at that, Nehal. First of all, I think Steve mentioned earlier, we have a range of -- in our gross margin model, 27% to 32% that provides that -- at certain times, we have different utilizations. Our different with product transitions, et cetera. But for this quarter-over-quarter decline, it is mainly a cost issue stemming from some more under absorption. We mentioned the gaming business. We mentioned the Toshiba business. There is also some price alignment in there, some quarter-over-quarter price takedowns. But we're actually fairly happy with the fact that given the macro headwinds and the demand situation that we can be well within our business model.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Keith Bachman with Bank of Montréal.
componenttext: The next question comes from Keith Bachman with Bank of Montréal.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I have 2 also. If you go back and just speak to the difference, you're guiding the 10 to be slight sequentially in revenues to be down quite materially sequentially. Could you talk about your pricing assumptions versus the mix assumptions and what's in th
componenttext: I have 2 also. If you go back and just speak to the difference, you're guiding the 10 to be slight sequentially in revenues to be down quite materially sequentially. Could you talk about your pricing assumptions versus the mix assumptions and what's in that revenue guidance, please? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's really 3 factors, Keith, that contributed to revenue down. First is the gaming business, and that's a project-based business as well. And that's a couple of million units going down quarter-over-quarter. The contract manufacturing for Toshiba
componenttext: Yes. There's really 3 factors, Keith, that contributed to revenue down. First is the gaming business, and that's a project-based business as well. And that's a couple of million units going down quarter-over-quarter. The contract manufacturing for Toshiba on the 3.5-inch divestiture, really peaked last quarter and it's quite a bit down as well. And then there are some price adjustments in the quarter-over-quarter price declines. It's really tough to put a exact percentages but you should think about it roughly 1/3, 1/3, 1/3.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Any comments on what you think like-for-like pricing will be?
componenttext: Okay. Any comments on what you think like-for-like pricing will be?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: We'll not expect that all.
componenttext: We'll not expect that all.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think if you want to -- I mean, Keith, you saw a little bit of color there. I mean we continues to be in a competitive marketplace. We've asserted that for a long time. But in terms of pricing behavior, I would not characterize anything that we're seein
componenttext: I think if you want to -- I mean, Keith, you saw a little bit of color there. I mean we continues to be in a competitive marketplace. We've asserted that for a long time. But in terms of pricing behavior, I would not characterize anything that we're seeing as getting out of balance. There's another word, irrational.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up though, if I could stick that in, I maybe over the quarter. Mike what about what are the conditions that will enable the TAM to be up in the March quarter, which is implicit within the 600 number, 600-million-unit number. I'm a little s
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up though, if I could stick that in, I maybe over the quarter. Mike what about what are the conditions that will enable the TAM to be up in the March quarter, which is implicit within the 600 number, 600-million-unit number. I'm a little surprised I'm not sure how we get there. I'm assuming within that balance, the Windows 8 balance, when does a dusk we.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that we got to get there either. I think you have to see one of few different things. One thing working in our industry's favor, potentially is we can get some of this inventory adjustment stuff behind us. That's early has been the suppressin
componenttext: I'm not sure that we got to get there either. I think you have to see one of few different things. One thing working in our industry's favor, potentially is we can get some of this inventory adjustment stuff behind us. That's early has been the suppressing our TAM. And we, in terms of our company and what we're trying to do, we don't want to carry that over. We'd like to see that adjustment work its way through as soon as possible. And we don't want to push on that strength. Additionally, it would be nice to see improvement in the macroeconomic environment, whether that happens to be a some certainty -- I mean, you guys know we've got elections, we've got changes of government, we've got fiscal cliff, et cetera, et cetera, right? Lots of different things that undoubtedly are impacting spending on the corporate and the consumer level. So I think that some clarity on those kind of activities would be helpful. And then also it would be nice to see some excitement around Windows 8. We're actually relatively -- when I say bullish, I mean maybe people are looking for good news but my experience, I think, has got some excitement to it. And I think it's really lack is that we've got to create some more excitement around the products out there. And we're trying to do our best in terms of some of these hybrid designs and smaller form factor designs that may be enable our customers to get a little bit excitement back to the product set.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the last conversation. Just curious, any more specifics you may have around now that we're days away from the Win 8 launch, when we might see an update in hybrid or the HDD shipments, with some of the new form factors that are planning
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the last conversation. Just curious, any more specifics you may have around now that we're days away from the Win 8 launch, when we might see an update in hybrid or the HDD shipments, with some of the new form factors that are planning to come to market?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when we talked about are hybrid designs, what we're doing right now is we are providing engineering samples to our customers. And then in the first half of calendar 2013, we will be supplying call samples and gearing up for volume kind of activity
componenttext: Yes. So when we talked about are hybrid designs, what we're doing right now is we are providing engineering samples to our customers. And then in the first half of calendar 2013, we will be supplying call samples and gearing up for volume kind of activity in the back half of 2013. So we have to watch our traction and our continued ability to execute from an engineering standpoint. And so we're still a bit far away but so far, the response from our customers has been encouraging.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: And it sounds like that line's up with the second iteration of win 8 products that Intel has launched for the quarter next year.
componenttext: And it sounds like that line's up with the second iteration of win 8 products that Intel has launched for the quarter next year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick clarification, there is a big jump in CE units in the September quarter. I know gaming has come up a number of times. But can you just talk about what drove that incremental 4 million units and how much of that you would expect to g
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick clarification, there is a big jump in CE units in the September quarter. I know gaming has come up a number of times. But can you just talk about what drove that incremental 4 million units and how much of that you would expect to get back in the next few quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the upside was gaming and it's a very seasonal business and I won't give an exact number but it's several million that can go up and down in a different order.
componenttext: Well, the upside was gaming and it's a very seasonal business and I won't give an exact number but it's several million that can go up and down in a different order.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to revisit the cost cutting and the reduced operating expenses. Wolfgang, I don't know if I got this number right. But I think you guided just $525 million for operating expenses for the December quarter, which is down about $40 million. I w
componenttext: I just wanted to revisit the cost cutting and the reduced operating expenses. Wolfgang, I don't know if I got this number right. But I think you guided just $525 million for operating expenses for the December quarter, which is down about $40 million. I wanted to get a sense of where you think you can take those cost actions. Is that reducing some of your R&D? Clearly, you have to do something in SG&A. And then just trying to get a sense of what type of percentage you expect RAD to be as a percent of sales as we move forward?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me state first, we are not cutting RAD at this point. I mean, where we're cutting costs out from the $550 million level is in discretionary spending. And we have also some of our variable pay that I'm not paying out a circle level. In terms of
componenttext: Yes, so let me state first, we are not cutting RAD at this point. I mean, where we're cutting costs out from the $550 million level is in discretionary spending. And we have also some of our variable pay that I'm not paying out a circle level. In terms of R&D in total, it's about 70% of our OpEx but if you're operating right now at about 14%, 15%, you close 10% on R&D. Once we get in the future, and our target model of 10% to 12%, it would be around 8%.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. 8%. And then thinking about investments as we move forward in terms of CapEx spending, what are your expectations for investments and having new equipment as we move forward. It looks like we kind of peaked the CapEx here at 382 in the September qua
componenttext: Okay. 8%. And then thinking about investments as we move forward in terms of CapEx spending, what are your expectations for investments and having new equipment as we move forward. It looks like we kind of peaked the CapEx here at 382 in the September quarter. I would assume that would go down and how much would you be expecting to add over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, first of all, I think you're right, the 382 is probably a peak. I want to remind you that we report CapEx on a cash basis so the 382 includes what related spending that was actually for capital that was received in Q4. With that before that i
componenttext: Yes. I mean, first of all, I think you're right, the 382 is probably a peak. I want to remind you that we report CapEx on a cash basis so the 382 includes what related spending that was actually for capital that was received in Q4. With that before that in total, we expect for flood recovery about $400 million, which approximately half will be in fiscal year '13. Our spending is focused on a couple of things. We're obviously investing in technology of RAM. We're investing in process improvements and product transitions and we're also investing in security of the supply chain and flexibility. We're investing almost nothing in capacity other than what is required to transition the line from an older generation to a newer generation. We expect that we will be well within our business model of 5% to 7%, if you take out the flood-related spending at the lower end or possibly the lower end of the model.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ben Reitzes with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ben Reitzes with Barclays.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: My first question is just with regard to the inventory that you talked about in the industry. Did you quantify that? And any idea on when that is lifted and why it's there? A little more detail on that.
componenttext: My first question is just with regard to the inventory that you talked about in the industry. Did you quantify that? And any idea on when that is lifted and why it's there? A little more detail on that.

componenttext: Well, I think that -- I'm not sure I agree or disagree. I think that there's a lot of different dynamics that are going on. headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2013. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the conference over to your host, Mr. Bob
componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to Western Digital's First Quarter Financial Results for Fiscal Year 2013. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. Now I will turn the conference over to your host, Mr. Bob Blair. You may begin.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements on our comments and in response your questions concerning growth in the storage industry, our position in the industry, our investment in capital allocation
componenttext:
Thank you. As we begin, I would like to mention that we will be making forward-looking statements on our comments and in response your questions concerning growth in the storage industry, our position in the industry, our investment in capital allocation plans, HDD demand for the December quarter and fiscal 2013 and our financial results expectations for the September quarter and fiscal 2013. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially, including those listed in our 10-K filed with the SEC on August 20, 2012. We undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect new information or events. 
In addition, references will be made during this call to non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the differences between the historical non-GAAP measures that we provide during this call to the comparable GAAP financial measures are included in the investor information summary posted in the Investor Relations section of our website. 
The forward-looking guidance we provide during this call excludes certain items such as amortization of intangibles and the dilutive impact of sales of drives to Toshiba in connection with our divestiture transaction. Because the amount of these items is not fully known to us at this time, we are unable to provide guidance for or our reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. The impact of these excluded items may cause the estimated non-GAAP financial measures to differ materially from the comparable GAAP financial measures. 
[Operator Instructions] I also want to note that copies of remarks from today's call will be available on the Investor section of Western Digital's website immediately following the conclusion of this call. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chief Executive Officer John Coyne.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. I have with me our President, Steve Milligan; and our Chief Financial Officer, Wolfgang Nickl. In this, my last earnings call, I'm happy to report another quarter of strong financial pe
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. I have with me our President, Steve Milligan; and our Chief Financial Officer, Wolfgang Nickl. 
In this, my last earnings call, I'm happy to report another quarter of strong financial performance, continuing our track record of consistent execution. During my 6-year tenure as CEO, we have experienced and successfully addressed many different challenges and opportunities. Throughout, we have continued to hone our time-tested and flexible business model, delivering outstanding returns and value under varying scenarios. The results include a doubling of market share, a tripling of revenue and a fivefold increase in profits. 
I'm proud of this sustained performance by the team, and I'm confident as I pass the leadership of the company to Steve, ably supported by Tim Laden, Mike Cordano and Wolfgang, that they will continue to build on that momentum. 
While the macroeconomic environment is dampening near-term demand, we remain confident in the continued long-term growth in the creation, storage and management of digital content. This is being seen in every aspect of our lives, and monetizing it provides a compelling long-term opportunity for the company. 
We have built strong relationships with customers in all of our markets by consistently delighting them with high-quality, reliable products based on superior technology and delivered through the industry's most efficient supply chain. We have developed a tremendously broad product portfolio, great depth and breadth in our people and technology resources and a powerful platform. Western Digital has never been better positioned to succeed as it continues to thrive on change and deliver great value to all its constituents. 
I want to take this opportunity to thank our customers, our supply partners and our investors for their support, and I especially want to thank our employees around the world who have consistently delivered such outstanding performance. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Steve Milligan.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. We are very pleased to report strong financial results for our September quarter, demonstrating our continued ability to deliver value under varying market conditions. There are several dynamics currently limiting market demand: first, globa
componenttext:
Thanks, John. We are very pleased to report strong financial results for our September quarter, demonstrating our continued ability to deliver value under varying market conditions. There are several dynamics currently limiting market demand: first, global macroeconomic weakness, which is impacting overall IT spending; second, product transitions in the PC industry; and third, the continued adoption of tablets and smartphones, which is meeting PC sales growth. 
These headwinds notwithstanding, the Western Digital team remains focused on creating outstanding economic value, building on our strong multiyear track record. There is a tremendous opportunity as we innovate and enable customers to store, manage and connect the massive and growing amounts of digital data in their personal and professional lives. This opportunity extends well into the future. 
Looking across our markets, the needs of customers are becoming more diverse, resulting in greater market segmentation. Computing is no longer a general purpose opposition, and that evolution plays to the strengths of Western Digital with our technology breadth, people and product portfolio. 
Currently, we are focused on 3 key initiatives to broaden our portfolio to meet the evolving needs of our customers, enabling continued value creation: first, the delivery of innovative and cost-effective storage products, including hybrid drives for thin and light mobile devices; second, a portfolio of enterprise products that fit the varying needs of the public and private cloud environments, including high-performance SSD systems and high-performance and large-capacity hard drives with the lowest total cost of ownership; third, providing easy-to-use integrated solutions for the personal cloud environment and our connected lives. 
We have received very positive customer feedback on our latest differentiated solutions to address these trends. All major PC OEMs have shown strong interest in our 5-millimeter and 7-millimeter hybrid designs as an alternative to solid-state and dual drive configurations. 
In the cloud environment, our new 7-disk high-capacity sealed drive announcement has been extremely well received, confirming the need to seek better total cost of ownership solutions for this growing market. For the Connected Life, we introduced today the My Passport Enterprise, one of the industry's first portable hard drives designed specifically for use with Microsoft's Windows To Go, enabling corporate customers to provision a fully featured Windows 8 workspace on a USB drive. 
For fiscal 2013, we remain focused on realizing the $10 EPS target established in July of this year despite a significant change in the underlying industry growth assumptions. We will continue to manage closely those aspects of our business that we control, namely delighting our customers, executing to our product roadmap, remaining diligent with regards to managing costs and expenses and strategically allocating our capital. 
Looking forward, I am very excited about the future of Western Digital. We have the people, platform, technology and financial resources to continue to invest in growth opportunities while at the same time, returning approximately 50% of our free cash flow to shareholders. 
Wolfgang will now provide a report on our Q1 performance and our Q2 outlook.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. I will first summarize our consolidated financial performance for last quarter and then provide a range of expected financial results for the December quarter. Revenue for the September quarter was $4 billion. Excluding shipment to Toshi
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. I will first summarize our consolidated financial performance for last quarter and then provide a range of expected financial results for the December quarter. Revenue for the September quarter was $4 billion. Excluding shipment to Toshiba under our divestiture agreement, we shifted total of 62.5 million hard drives into the market at an average selling price of $62. 
OEM sales represented 63% of revenue; distribution channel sales, 24%; and retail sales, 13%. Our gross margin for the quarter was 29.6%. Excluding $38 million of amortization expense related to acquired HGST intangible assets, non-GAAP gross margin was 30.5%. Our R&D and SG&A spending totaled $575 million for the September quarter. SG&A included $11 million of amortization expense related to acquired HGST intangible assets. 
In order to align our production with anticipated market demand, we incurred charges of $26 million in the September quarter. Net interest and other non-operating expense was $14 million. Tax expense for the September quarter was $59 million or 10.2% of pretax income. Our net income for the September quarter totaled $519 million or $2.06 per share. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $594 million or $2.36 per share. 
Turning to the balance sheet. We generated $936 million in cash from operations during the September quarter, and our free cash flow totaled $554 million. We used $218 million to repurchase 5.2 million shares. As of the end of September, an authorization of $2.6 billion remains available for future repurchases. 
We declared the first dividend in company history in the amount of $0.25 per share or a total of $61 million, which we paid on October 15 to shareholders of record as of September 28. 
We exited fiscal Q1 with total cash and cash equivalent of $3.5 billion, of which $826 million was in the U.S. Subtracting our total debt of $2.1 billion, our net cash balance was $1.4 billion.
I will now provide our guidance for the December quarter. We expect a total available market of approximately 140 million units; revenue in the range of $3.55 billion to $3.7 billion, reflecting the muted demand environment, a seasonal reduction in our gaming business and a planned reduction of our 3.5-inch contract manufacturing for Toshiba; gross margin of approximately 28%, excluding the amortization of HGST intangibles, which is within our new business model despite continued cost challenges stemming from the floods in Thailand last year. We expect R&D and SG&A spending to be approximately $525 million, excluding the amortization of HGST intangibles; a tax rate of approximately 8.5%; and a share count of approximately 248 million. Accordingly, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share of between $1.65 and $1.85 for the December quarter. 
Operator, we are now ready to open the call for questions.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert Baird.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to ask Steve about macro cyclical and secular. I know it's tough to divide that up, Steve. But if you could talk about how much of this is secular versus cyclical assuming the macro comes back or gets better next year. So some more color t
componenttext: First, I wanted to ask Steve about macro cyclical and secular. I know it's tough to divide that up, Steve. But if you could talk about how much of this is secular versus cyclical assuming the macro comes back or gets better next year. So some more color there.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, Jason, you kind of hit the nail on the head. I think that it's a difficult question to answer. I mean, we've got -- I mean, as we indicated on our prepared remarks, there's a lot of different factors at play. Clearly, the global macroeconomic
componenttext: Yes. I mean, Jason, you kind of hit the nail on the head. I think that it's a difficult question to answer. I mean, we've got -- I mean, as we indicated on our prepared remarks, there's a lot of different factors at play. Clearly, the global macroeconomic environment, I mean -- and it's not just the IT industry, but there's a lot of headwinds in terms of what's happening on a global basis. Additionally, the IT segment is not immune to that. So we've seen other announcements come out that have talked about weakness in terms of overall IT spending. And then clearly, the PC industry is weak, all right. And some of that is due to product transitions with Windows 8. But undoubtedly, there is an impact, as we're seeing, if you want to call it cannibalization in terms of tablets and smartphones or other kind of connected devices. And I think the important thing to really refer to is when we had our Investor Day, we talked about a longer-term growth rate in the HDD industry of 3%. When we put that together, we attempted as best as possible to estimate the impact of all these different factors. And right now, we don't see a reason to alter that 3% longer-term growth rate in terms of a number of hard drives sold.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Wolfgang, you maintained $10 for the full year. You must be assuming gross margins come up off that 28% level in the second half of the year, fiscal year?
componenttext: Okay. And Wolfgang, you maintained $10 for the full year. You must be assuming gross margins come up off that 28% level in the second half of the year, fiscal year?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason. I mean, $10 is the target and remains the target. Our complete focus is on the items that we control or at least influence. We're focusing heavily on cost. We're focusing on OpEx and spending. We somewhat impact the share count as well and obv
componenttext: Yes, Jason. I mean, $10 is the target and remains the target. Our complete focus is on the items that we control or at least influence. We're focusing heavily on cost. We're focusing on OpEx and spending. We somewhat impact the share count as well and obviously try to optimize volume price mix decision. So we're focusing on what we control or influence. We have made an assumption when we originally stated the $10 target in July, I believe, yes, in July, that we assumed the TAM to increase by 5%. And if you do the math, that would be a TAM of 630 million units. And with the first 2 quarters, that 139 and 140, respectively, we need a bit of an uptick in the second half of the fiscal year to continue to be able to do the target. I believe that we'll get in the 600 range. It's very doable. And like we said, we focus on the levels that we control. And it remains a target, and that's what we're shooting for.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Rob Cihra with Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Next question comes from Rob Cihra with Evercore Partners.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Wondering within the product mix in the quarter, if you could give us any more color both within PC but even more so, I guess, on enterprise. How much of that decline in the quarter that maybe you're expecting again? Do you think it's inventory drawdown v
componenttext: Wondering within the product mix in the quarter, if you could give us any more color both within PC but even more so, I guess, on enterprise. How much of that decline in the quarter that maybe you're expecting again? Do you think it's inventory drawdown versus actual slowdown in demand? And again, maybe perhaps more so on the enterprise side given the fact that we kind of already know that PCs have been weak, but any view you have in the enterprise demand, what it's looking like?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rob. In the enterprise space, there's a couple of different dynamics going on. First thing is if you go back to the floods, really a couple of different things there. First off, the enterprise segment was the one segment that was least impacted from
componenttext: Sure, Rob. In the enterprise space, there's a couple of different dynamics going on. First thing is if you go back to the floods, really a couple of different things there. First off, the enterprise segment was the one segment that was least impacted from a drive output perspective as it relates to the floods. We all -- the various different companies independently did as much as we could to protect the supply in that critical part of the market. Nevertheless, our customers, because of concerns about shortages, I would say, bought ahead from a demand perspective in order to protect themselves in that segment. Additionally, if you look at some of the impact of the LTA contracts that were out there, that also resulted in customers purchasing ahead from a supply perspective ahead of the demand. And then, sure, we have seen some slowdown in terms of end-user demand, if you want to refer to it that way. But fundamentally, the overall dynamics in the enterprise space remain positive as we're seeing substantial data growth and build-out of infrastructures from that perspective. However, in terms of the units that we ship as an industry and we ship as a company, we are seeing the impact of that inventory correction roll through the latest quarter. And hopefully, we'll be able to work our way through it as we finish out the year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012

componenttext: Next question comes from Steve Fox with Cross Research.

componenttext: Just a couple of quick clarifications. Just on the $10 target, just to return to that for a second. If you're talking about potentially doing 600 million units in sort of the bogey, what would be the levers that you think you can most control, putting aside capital allocation? Would it be more on the expense side? Or would it be shipping new products sooner than maybe has been advertised, et cetera? And then secondly, is there any other mix issues that we should think of maybe over the next couple of quarters within the segments in terms of average capacity, within notebooks versus hard -- versus desktops, et cetera, as we model out?

componenttext: Yes. I would just add to that, and I mean, certainly what we can do on the cost and expense side is always important to manage that in a diligent fashion. But our #1 priority is to continue to take care of our customers because if we can earn their trust and continue to earn their business, that helps provide the runway for stronger financial results for us.
