But in terms of pricing behavior, I would not characterize anything that we're seeing as anything out of balance, or here's another word, irrational.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, great. My follow-up though, if I could sneak that in. I may be over my quota, but just what are the conditions that would enable the TAM to be up in the March quarter, which is implicit within the 600 number, 600-million-unit number. I'm a lit
componenttext: Okay, okay, great. My follow-up though, if I could sneak that in. I may be over my quota, but just what are the conditions that would enable the TAM to be up in the March quarter, which is implicit within the 600 number, 600-million-unit number. I'm a little surprised, and I'm not sure how we get there. Are you assuming within that a big 8 bounce, a Windows 8 bounce?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure that we know how to get there either. I mean, we're, I mean -- but I think that you'd have to see one of a few different things. One thing working in our industry's favor, potentially, is we can get some of this inventory adjustment stu
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure that we know how to get there either. I mean, we're, I mean -- but I think that you'd have to see one of a few different things. One thing working in our industry's favor, potentially, is we can get some of this inventory adjustment stuff behind us. That certainly has been suppressing our TAM. And we, in terms of our company and what we're trying to do, we don't want to carry that over. We'd like to see that adjustment work its way through as soon as possible. And we don't want to push on that string. Additionally, it would be nice to see some improvement in the macroeconomic environment, whether that happens to be some certainty in -- and I mean, you guys know all of this, but we've got elections, we've got changes of government, we've got fiscal cliff, et cetera, et cetera, right, lots of different things that undoubtedly are impacting spending at a corporate and a consumer level. So I think that some clarity on those kind of activities would be helpful. And then also, it would be nice to see some excitement around Windows 8. We're actually relatively -- when I say bullish, I mean, maybe people are looking for good news, but my experience, I think it's got some excitement to it. And I think the thing that has really lacked is that we've got to create some more excitement around the products out there. And we're trying to do our best in terms of some of these hybrid designs and smaller form factor designs that maybe enable our customers to have a little bit of excitement back to the product set.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the last conversation. Just curious, any more specifics you may have around now that we're days away from the Win 8 launch, when we might see an uptick in hybrid or the thin HDD shipments with some of the new form factors that are plan
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the last conversation. Just curious, any more specifics you may have around now that we're days away from the Win 8 launch, when we might see an uptick in hybrid or the thin HDD shipments with some of the new form factors that are planning to come to market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when we talked about our hybrid designs, I mean, what we're doing right now is we are providing engineering samples to our customers. And then in the first half of calendar 2013, we will be supplying call samples and gearing up for volume kind of
componenttext: Yes. So when we talked about our hybrid designs, I mean, what we're doing right now is we are providing engineering samples to our customers. And then in the first half of calendar 2013, we will be supplying call samples and gearing up for volume kind of activity the back half of 2013. So we have to watch our traction and our continued ability to execute from an engineering standpoint. And so we're still a bit far away, but so far, the response from our customers has been encouraging.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: And it sounds like that lines up with the second iteration of thin and light Win 8 products that we'd get after the Intel Haswell launch in the second quarter next year.
componenttext: And it sounds like that lines up with the second iteration of thin and light Win 8 products that we'd get after the Intel Haswell launch in the second quarter next year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Correct, correct.
componenttext: Correct, correct.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a quick clarification. There was a big jump in CE units in the September quarter. I know gaming has come up a number of times. But can you just talk about what drove that incremental 4 million units and how much of that you would expec
componenttext: Okay. And then just a quick clarification. There was a big jump in CE units in the September quarter. I know gaming has come up a number of times. But can you just talk about what drove that incremental 4 million units and how much of that you would expect to give back in the next few quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the upside was [indiscernible] by gaming, and it's a very seasonal business. And I won't give you an exact number, but it's several million that can go up and down in a given quarter.
componenttext: Well, the upside was [indiscernible] by gaming, and it's a very seasonal business. And I won't give you an exact number, but it's several million that can go up and down in a given quarter.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Sherri Scribner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to revisit the cost cutting and the reduced operating expenses. Wolfgang, I don't know if I got this number right. But I think you've guided to $525 million for operating expenses for the December quarter, which is down about $40 million. I
componenttext: I just wanted to revisit the cost cutting and the reduced operating expenses. Wolfgang, I don't know if I got this number right. But I think you've guided to $525 million for operating expenses for the December quarter, which is down about $40 million. I wanted to get a sense of where you think you can take those cost actions. Is that reducing some of your R&D? Clearly, you'll have to do something in SG&A. And then just trying to get a sense of what type of percentage you expect R&D to be as a percent of sales as we move forward.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me state first, we are not cutting R&D at this point. I mean, where we're cutting costs out from the $550 million level is in discretionary spending. And we have also some of our variable pay programs that are not paying at the historical leve
componenttext: Yes. So let me state first, we are not cutting R&D at this point. I mean, where we're cutting costs out from the $550 million level is in discretionary spending. And we have also some of our variable pay programs that are not paying at the historical level. In terms of R&D in total, it's about 70% of our OpEx. But if you're operating right now at about 14%, 15%, you're close to 10% on R&D. Once we get in the future and our target model of 10% to 12%, it would be around 8%.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, 8%. And then thinking about investments as we move forward in terms of CapEx spending, what are your expectations for investments and adding new equipment as we move forward? It looks like we kind of peaked the CapEx here at 382 in the September qua
componenttext: Okay, 8%. And then thinking about investments as we move forward in terms of CapEx spending, what are your expectations for investments and adding new equipment as we move forward? It looks like we kind of peaked the CapEx here at 382 in the September quarter. I would assume that would go down. And how much capacity would you be expecting to add over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, first of all, I think you're right, the 382 is probably a peak. I want to remind you that we report CapEx on a cash basis, so the 382 includes flood-related spending that was actually for capital that was received in Q4. With that, before tha
componenttext: Yes. I mean, first of all, I think you're right, the 382 is probably a peak. I want to remind you that we report CapEx on a cash basis, so the 382 includes flood-related spending that was actually for capital that was received in Q4. With that, before that, in total, we expect for flood recovery about $400 million, for which approximately half will be in fiscal year '13. Our spending is focused on a couple of things. We're obviously investing in technology ramp. We're investing in process improvements and product transitions, and we're also investing in security of the supply chain and flexibility. We're investing almost nothing in capacity other than what is required to transition the line from an older generation to a newer generation. We expect that we will be well within our business model of 5% to 7%, if you take out the flood-related spending at the lower end or possibly the lower end of the model.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ben Reitzes with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ben Reitzes with Barclays.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: My first question is just with regard to the inventory that you talked about in the industry. Did you quantify that? And any idea on when that is lifted and why it's there? A little more detail on that.
componenttext: My first question is just with regard to the inventory that you talked about in the industry. Did you quantify that? And any idea on when that is lifted and why it's there? A little more detail on that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did not quantify it, and it would be speculation to try to actually estimate it. But we -- now it obviously depends upon we're one player, granted a big player in the industry. And also, it is -- we've got customers and their behavior. But our int
componenttext: Yes, we did not quantify it, and it would be speculation to try to actually estimate it. But we -- now it obviously depends upon we're one player, granted a big player in the industry. And also, it is -- we've got customers and their behavior. But our intent would be to try to eliminate that inventory overhang here before we exit calendar 2012.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: And it's also important, Ben, the -- we continue to operate the channel in an extremely clean fashion. The distribution inventory, including in transit, is significantly less than 3 weeks -- excuse me, 4 weeks.
componenttext: And it's also important, Ben, the -- we continue to operate the channel in an extremely clean fashion. The distribution inventory, including in transit, is significantly less than 3 weeks -- excuse me, 4 weeks.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just my follow-up's real quick on share repurchase. If you take your $10 guidance as literal, it means about $3 in earnings probably in the March and June quarters. I mean, is there any thought about accelerating share repurchase now so that you
componenttext: Okay. And just my follow-up's real quick on share repurchase. If you take your $10 guidance as literal, it means about $3 in earnings probably in the March and June quarters. I mean, is there any thought about accelerating share repurchase now so that you have a lower share count for when you have to hit those numbers? Or I guess my question is why not buy back more now and front-load the year with regard to returning your 50% or however much of that goes to buybacks now versus later?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's certainly one of the levels available to us, and we're exploring that.
componenttext: It's certainly one of the levels available to us, and we're exploring that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan Chase.
componenttext: Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just building on Ben's question there around the $10 target, I had a question in terms of the 3 initiatives that Steve mentioned earlier in the call. Are those tantamount or necessary to get to that $10 target? Do you need those to step down as buffers to
componenttext: Just building on Ben's question there around the $10 target, I had a question in terms of the 3 initiatives that Steve mentioned earlier in the call. Are those tantamount or necessary to get to that $10 target? Do you need those to step down as buffers to some of these other dynamics around cannibalization of PCs from smartphones and tablets and other stuff?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you go back, Mark, and you look at what we've talked about in terms of hybrid drive, as well as the helium drive, I assume that's what you're referring to, both of those are not expected to contribute materially to our financial results u
componenttext: Well, I think if you go back, Mark, and you look at what we've talked about in terms of hybrid drive, as well as the helium drive, I assume that's what you're referring to, both of those are not expected to contribute materially to our financial results until the back half of 2013, calendar 2013. But obviously, we need to continue to execute on our broader product roadmap, bring on improvements in terms of our execution against aerial density curves, all those different kinds of things.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up question is related to the inventory overhang. Do you think the inventory overhang was driven by some of these long-term agreements that were signed with your competitor earlier this year and that they went to maybe a selective suppl
componenttext: And then my follow-up question is related to the inventory overhang. Do you think the inventory overhang was driven by some of these long-term agreements that were signed with your competitor earlier this year and that they went to maybe a selective supply chain or bridge here from some of the OEMs and that's what we're having to clean out?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: That certainly contributed to it, yes, Mark.
componenttext: That certainly contributed to it, yes, Mark.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then maybe as a last follow-up. As a result of those long-term agreements probably ending here pretty soon, have you seen increased discussions certainly from the server and storage OEMs to do more and more business with Western Digital going forward?
componenttext: And then maybe as a last follow-up. As a result of those long-term agreements probably ending here pretty soon, have you seen increased discussions certainly from the server and storage OEMs to do more and more business with Western Digital going forward? Because I know a lot of OEMs are kind of disappointed how Seagate did take advantage of that unfortunate situation in Thailand last year.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we talked about it earlier in terms of what we've done in the enterprise segment, and I think there's a lot of different dynamics. The commercial aspect of the relationship is only one aspect. There's also the product aspect, quality as
componenttext: Well, I think that we talked about it earlier in terms of what we've done in the enterprise segment, and I think there's a lot of different dynamics. The commercial aspect of the relationship is only one aspect. There's also the product aspect, quality aspect, just how you deal with the relationship. So I don't -- I think it's difficult to isolate one particular variable. And what we really have been focused on, frankly, for quite a while is building longer-term endearing relationships with our customers. And we're going to continue to do that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And thank you, John, for your consistent execution and messaging over the years. Really appreciated it.
componenttext: Okay. And thank you, John, for your consistent execution and messaging over the years. Really appreciated it.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much.
componenttext: Thank you very much.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mark Miller with Noble Financial Capital Market.
componenttext: Mark Miller with Noble Financial Capital Market.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I also like to add that sentiment, John. You've done a very good job with this firm. I guess the question that everyone has, and I know you were asked this before. But there are scenarios out there saying that there is currently production constraints or
componenttext: I also like to add that sentiment, John. You've done a very good job with this firm. I guess the question that everyone has, and I know you were asked this before. But there are scenarios out there saying that there is currently production constraints or shortages of flash chips, and with the fabs that are going up, it's going to be hard for flash and then solid state drives to keep on taking -- to keep on cannibalizing drive and PC sales at the rate they've been doing over the last couple of years. Do you agree or disagree with that?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that -- I'm not sure I agree or disagree. I think that there's a lot of different dynamics that are going on. And I think that demand is down for a lot of different reasons, and to try to isolate it to -- it's not so much that SSD, or solid
componenttext: Well, I think that -- I'm not sure I agree or disagree. I think that there's a lot of different dynamics that are going on. And I think that demand is down for a lot of different reasons, and to try to isolate it to -- it's not so much that SSD, or solid state, is taking over the world right now. Demand just isn't very good across the board. And so I think that we've got to look at it in a broader context. Yes, there is some impact, but I don't think that, that's the only dynamic that's occurring.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, just to follow up on that question. I believe Stephen Luczo said it during their Investor Day that he actually thought that the macroenvironment as well as the product transitions were having a bigger effect on demand and tablet cannibalization. Do
componenttext: Well, just to follow up on that question. I believe Stephen Luczo said it during their Investor Day that he actually thought that the macroenvironment as well as the product transitions were having a bigger effect on demand and tablet cannibalization. Do you agree or disagree with that?

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair statement. I would tend to agree with that.
componenttext: I think that's a fair statement. I would tend to agree with that.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: That concludes today's call. Thank you, everyone. We appreciate your questions and look forward to being in touch in the months ahead through our investor relations activities. I want to finish with an expression of thanks, admiration and congratulations
componenttext: That concludes today's call. Thank you, everyone. We appreciate your questions and look forward to being in touch in the months ahead through our investor relations activities. I want to finish with an expression of thanks, admiration and congratulations to John Coyne for his 30 years of dedicated service to Western Digital, including the last 6 as CEO. He and his team have put Western Digital on a course to create significant additional value for our customers and employees and shareholders in the years ahead. I look forward to being part of that next phase in the company's rich history.

headline: Western Digital Corporation, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This does conclude the conference. You may disconnect at this time.
componenttext: Thank you. This does conclude the conference. You may disconnect at this time.
